roleset.name: cause, required to undergo, contingent upon some procedure, experience

example.name: passivized
example.text: That meant no trading would occur in the final seconds , as a way of making sure that last - second orders are n't subjected to a sudden price swing that would upset customers .

propbank.arg: to a sudden price swing that would upset customers

example.name: ARG0 and ARG1 and ARG2
example.text: He may take the Fifth in a civil matter only if he has a good faith and justifiable belief that his testimony may subject him to criminal prosecution .

example.name: adjectival rel: subject
example.text: If you are subject to a court order restraining from harassing , stalking , or threatening ...

propbank.arg: to a court order restraining from harassing , stalking , or threatening

example.name: adjectival, disambiguating example
example.text: The students were told that their lockers were subject to search .

roleset.note: SUBJECT-V NOTES: Frames file for 'subject' based on sentences in financial subcorpus, adjectival variant based on BOLT-1. NoVerbnet entry. (from subject.01-v)
SUBJECT-J NOTES: Automatically created by Julia as an alias file for unification. (from subject.01-j)

roleset.name: prone, likely to be affected by

example.name: All args
example.text: The small child was subject to colds and fever .

example.name: All args
example.text: The network is subject to failure .

roleset.note: SUBJECT-J NOTES:02 sense arose in AMR unification discussion, framed by Claire. Consider whether or not an outside causer makessense when distinguishing these two senses. No one (outside ofdeities perhaps) subjects children or networks to colds and failure,but an Agent is present in causing lockers to be searched.

roleset.name: particular to person experience

example.name: subjective-j
example.text: Stress is subjective ; it makes different people feel different things

roleset.note: SUBJECTIVE-J NOTES: Added automatically by Julia. (from subjective.01-j)
